results.title: Dimples
results.creator_credit: William A. Seiter and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Shirley Temple collection”.
Shirley Temple stars in this delightful old-fashioned musical comedy. The cutest little girl with the biggest dimples, sings and dances her way from poverty to stardom. Ever cheerful, Little Dimples sings for money in the Bowery while her thieving Grandfather pickpockets the crowd she attracts. When a society lady adopts her, Dimples is discovered by the woman’s nephew who needs someone to play Little Eva in his upcoming production of ‘Uncle Tom’s cabin’. Charming and entertaining, this film is packed with laughs, tender moments and rousing musical numbers. This is a colourized version of the original black and white film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William A. Seiter and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation

results.title: Film graphics: abstract aspect of editing
results.creator_credit: Barry Spinello, Paul Aratow and Cine Qua Non-Bartholomus
results.brief_description: With pictures, animation and quotations from classical cinema, this film shows some of the basic structural principles of film composition and editing. Extracts from BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN, UN CHIEN ANDALOU, and MAN WITH A MOVIE CAMERA, show the use of abstract graphic structure in film editing.

results.title: Film Australia: immigration
results.creator_credit: Penelope McDonald, Paul Byrnes, Oasis DVD and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The Australian Migration scheme and Film Australia were both set up just after World War II and were under the one minister. Hand in hand they set about promoting and encouraging migration through the film medium. Films where also made to encourage acceptance of migrants for Australians. To this day the Film Australia Collection holds over 100 immigration films. This interesting and informative DVD presents edited versions of eight of the collections most important films. The films cover a period of time from the forties to the nineties with a contemporary short documentary containing interviews with some of the participants and the film makers of each of the eight films. “Film Australia Immigration” also presents a series of clips arranged by subjects such as language, food, and identity. An extremely fascinating and authoritative exploration of immigration in Australia.

results.title: Rebel music: the Bob Marley story
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Marre, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Thirteen and Antelope Films
results.brief_description: This documentary traces musician Bob Marley’s rise from the violence and poverty of the slums of Jamaica to become a cultural icon, symbol of Rastafarianism, black politics and civil rights. Initially Marley had difficulty in getting his music heard in Jamaica, but eventually his sound grew in popularity. Whilst travelling in America, Marley was influenced by images of the Afro-American uprising of the civil rights movement, causing his writing to become much more political. Upon his return to Jamaica Marley soon turned to Rastafarianism - a specifically Jamaican movement, banned under Colonial rule, that married black consciousness with spiritual awareness. Being a Rastafarian revolutionised Marley’s music and politics, making him a powerful force for the black human rights cause, as well as a political ally and danger to the leaders of the country. This documentary includes interviews with Rita Marley (his widow), Lee Scratch Perry, The Wailers, lovers, producers, collaborators, friends and colleagues in the music industry, politicians and family members. Contains archival footage of Marley, film clips, interviews and live shows. Songs include: Rebel music, Judge not, Soul rebel, Corner store, Put it on, One love, Stir it up and Its alright.

results.title: Film and you
results.creator_credit: Donald Peters, Jean Palardy, Donald Fraser and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film describes how film councils are organised, and what they can do for the community. Different people like different things - for instance, Grandpa, who goes to sleep during a sequence on kitchen planning, wakes joyfully at the sound of a square dance. But all groups agree that they want films on their programs, if they can get them, and that is where the film council comes in. Animation shows how a council is set up, and how a number of organisations in an area can collaborate in buying a projector. We see projectionist training, and the public library becoming a distribution centre for films as well as books. Finally, we see film in action, as a variety of successful community projects are carried out, each directly the result of film showings.

results.title: Filling time
results.creator_credit: Andy Walker, Colin Thomas, BBC and Aardman Animations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Animated Conversations”.
Another in the series of films whose starting point is the sound track, made by pinning a radio microphone to the central character. The resulting ‘natural conversation’ was edited down to five minutes and the animator allowed free visual interpretation. This one is about a visit to the dentist.
